title: White Sheet Hill - Stourton Walk Route

images.title: Colin Smith / White Sheet Hill, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: White Sheet Hill. Grassy hill seen from the Castle Hill at Mere.

images.title: Andrew Smith / White Sheet Hill, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The scarp northwest of the top of the hill. The corner of the arable field is just within this grid-square.

images.title: Phil Williams / White Sheet Hill, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A view looking west from the top of White Sheet hill. The cold war relic of the entrance hatch to the Royal Observer Corps observation post in the foreground contrasts with the neolithic tumulus in the background. Alfreds Tower can be seen on the horizon.

images.title: Andrew Smith / Tumulus, White Sheet Hill, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Tumulus on the hill. At the southeastern corner of a neolithic camp. The other signs of the camp are rather vague.

images.title: Maurice Pullin [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The partly cut wheat fields at the bottom of the hill give the impression of a seashore.

images.title: Phil Williams / Byway to White Sheet Hill, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A view looking west along the byway from Mere Down to White Sheet Hill, the summit of which can be seen in the distance. The sign on the gate post read " Keep Out - Site of Special Scientific Interest."

images.title: Phil Williams / Cattle on White Sheet Hill, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cattle on the hill

images.title: Trish Steel [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The bridleway crosses the Cross Dyke and then gives walkers and riders access to Woodland Down.

description: Climb to the 245 m (804 ft) summit of this hill in Wiltshire and enjoy wonderful views over the Stourhead Estate and the surrounding countryside. The hill is located about 2 miles to the east of Stourton. You can park at the Stourhead estate National Trust car park and follow footpaths to Drove Lodge before picking up a track to the hill. The area is covered with rare and protected fauna and flora including various wildflowers, several species of orchid, the chalkhill blue butterfly and the golden plover. It is also of archaeological significance with an Iron Age Hill Fort,  neolithic causeway camp and barrows. The views over the Cranborne Chase AONB and the Somerset, Dorset and Wiltshire countrsyside are extensive. If you would like to continue your walking in the area then you could explore the Stourhead Estate. Here you will find mile of footpaths taking you around an exquisite lake and through woodlands, parkland and gardens. You can also climb to the hill from the nearby town of Mere, which lies just to the south. The Stour Valley Way long distance trail starts at Stourton so you could pick up this waymarked trail to continue your walking in the area.
